comment.author: 39229971@N08
comment._content: That is Cathal Brugha front and centre with the hat and mac.  Brugha died of wounds received in action against Free State troops on 7th July, 1922.  Either Wikipedia is wrong with his date of death or the date in the catalogue is incorrect.  Worthy of further research methinks.

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content: Cheers Carol. Interesting of who might be who in this collective of  political & Social Irish personnel of the time!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/theyellabelly] Thanks, should have recognized Cathal Brugha myself. You're absolutely right - Brugha died on Friday, 7 July 1922, so that blows our original dating out of the water...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38896199@N06
comment._content: Is that Willie O Dea on the far right!

comment.author: 8087163@N05
comment._content: If we saw any (and I do mean that in a non party political way!) of the current lot smiling like that I think we'd stone them!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Seuss. has identified the bearded gentleman at the back as Count George Noble Plunkett. Fairly sure this is correct, although there are very few photos of Plunkett about that we can check against. However, Plunkett was Minister for Fine Arts (outside the cabinet) from August 1921 to January 1922, and was certainly involved with Eamon de Valera so it would make sense for him to be part of this group.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Looking at the faces it is easy to imagine names but that does not make them right.  I thought one looked like Erskine Childers Snr. but googling him shows a very different gentleman.  The Willie O'Dea lookalike could be Frank Aiken or Sean Lemass but as Lemass was just a youth he may not have had a moustache as good as that one.  The elderly lady is definitely Margaret Pearse as you will see from any of the photos that come up in Google!  As you say, it's not often the Long Fellow is seen in such a relaxed mood.  I have a feeling that the movie clip that is shown being taken is in the archives somewhere and may have appeared in the likes of Mise Eire?  If I remember correctly this was taken after the decision to break with the Pro-Treaty groupings and before the actual outbreak of hostilities.  Brugha and Collins thoroughly detested each other and Cathal was never likely to take Collins side in anything.

comment.author: 74533356@N08
comment._content: Joseph MacDonagh TD for Nth Tipp in front with hands in coat pocket

comment.author: 54082333@N00
comment._content: There is another photo of the same gathering on the National Library website, at least it's very similar with the same people in the same spots, Brugha is holding his hat and coat and the lady on the left of shot is also there with her coat. if there is a larger copy of that available perhaps it lists the people in the shot catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000218977 It also has a publish date of 10th July 1922

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Nice one descramble, that debunks my theory that the guy with the moustache might be Frank Aiken because big Frank is on the left of that picture with the hat on his head!  The chap with the 'tache is in more or less the same position which supports your thinking!

comment.author: 54082333@N00
comment._content: Looking at both pictures, and trying to find pics of anti-treaty TDs in the 3rd Dail, a last guess to end the night: Brian O'Higgins 2nd Row 1st Partly hidden. If we could see a large scan of the whole group I think he's looking at the camera and both kind of look like they could be him. freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~ccfgpw/ban-195... Update: I don't think it's him anymore. The hair looks wrong? catalogue.nli.ie/Record/KE_091 and in a drawing from the 1919 First Dail poster his hairline is far back (bottom row above "90th") so I think he might have had less hair in 1922??? irishelectionliterature.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/1stda... Update again: having looked at the larger photo I think it's him again

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/25230525@N06] Re: Desmond Fitzgerald: I think you could be right. I didnt think it myself at first but going through the 1st Dail photos he jumped out as the guy holding the flag and looking at other photos as well. Which would be interesting because from what I know and have read he was officially Pro-Treaty and part of the Provisional Government, though Garret Fitzgeralds bio below says his father (Desmond) "remained friendly with anti-treatyites" and his mother Mabel supported the republican side. www.generalmichaelcollins.com/Fine_Gael/Garrett_Fitzgeral... irishecho.com/?p=64680

comment._content: @descramble: I'm delighted someone else is sad enough to be preoccupied with this, haha! I was the guy who suggested Liam Mellows. comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: The man on the left hand of the back row reminds me of Kevin Boland whose father Gerald was a devotee of Dev.s and who would have been very much in his company at the time.  I've tried to find a photo of him but with little success.  It's amazing how few photographs there are of some of the most influential people involved in the beginning of our state!

comment.author: 54082333@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Yup that's the "Desmond", but I'd run the idea past some real historians first because Desmond Fitzgerald showing up in a photo at an Anti-Treaty event waving a flag could be news to some people :-) more pictures of him: RTE: www.rte.ie/news/2011/0519/fitzgeraldg.html (click onto the second picture in the slideshow and it shows Desmond, Garrets father) Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Desmond_FitzGerald.jpg

comment.author: 54082333@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/74659969@N03] You are right it could be Traynor, the forehead and hairline from the picture of him in old age are very similar (more similar than my suggestion of Moylan). comment.author: 38896199@N06
comment._content:
A few years ago Adobe added a facial recognition system to Photoshop, I know this seems like Star Wars stuff but if you add photographs who have been positively identified already, the system will give you a match or proposed match with every photograph you add thereafter. 

Naturally I thought it was rubbish but its not and many find it works every well, even Facebook etc are using similar now. Just an idea!

comment.author: 54082333@N00
comment._content: I dragged out my copy of a book called "The Irish Civil War" by Tim Pat Coogan & George Morrison, it's basically a photo book with some text explaining each photo. On Page 135 there are 2 photos from this photo call. It says the photos were taken on the steps of the National University on 10th January 1922. The text says it happened on the day the Dail voted for Arthur Griffith as President of the Dail to replace deValera. I'll add some IDs based on what this book says.

comment.author: 54082333@N00
comment._content: Added Sean McEntee (based on "The Irish Civil War")

comment.author: 54082333@N00
comment._content: Added Sean O'Mahony (based on sensibleken and entry in "The Irish Civil War")

comment.author: 54082333@N00
comment._content: Going back to the Desmond Fitzgerald question, here is another pic I found that may have been taken the same day. "Des" is holding the flag again. web.mst.edu/~greggjay/irstamp.html (just over half way down) Still can't tell 100% if it's him from that photo but if the photos were taken on the 10th of Jan when deValera walked out of the Dail then it can't be him since he (Deasmhumhain Mac Gearailt) stayed inside and voted for Griffith generalmichaelcollins.com/Treaty_Documents/The_Treaty_Deb...

comment.author: 79903783@N03
comment._content: Am pretty certain it isn't Desmond FitzGerald in the picture. FitzGerald at the time had a thinner face and his hair was different to the man in the picture. FitzGerald's cheekbones were more hollow than those of the guy in the picture in pictures of him at that time.
